body: Thanks @ivanov, I will be working with Laurent Gautier on moving rpy2 forward over the coming weeks, so it'd be great to coordinate this with work on improving Rmagic.

Is this just an issue of using git to pull these subdirectories out? It looks like `git subtree` might be a bit cleaner / maintain history better than git filter-branch:

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/359424/detach-subdirectory-into-separate-git-repository/17864475#17864475

Git docs here:

https://github.com/git/git/blob/master/contrib/subtree/git-subtree.txt

I'm happy to get started on this and just put them in my pesonal github account for now. Does code need to be changed as well to allow for magics to exist in external repos?
Extensions are not assumed to be a part of IPython, but we do ship a few.  All they have to be is importable. If rmagic were a regular Python module, `%load_ext rmagic` should work exactly the same.

followed up with @davclark  in meatspace on this, he will rip out the history of and make a new repo for rmagic.py and work on it. Once we officially break off the extensions into their own repos, we'll be able to grab the things he's working on
The above pull request raises a very important question: how are we going to handle docs after doing the split?
I think that the different cell magic repos will have their own example notebooks which will be a sliced up version of the notebook being updated in #3997

I know @davclark's a bit occupied for the time being, but there has recently been more activity, particularly in the R magic improvements, that I think it would make sense to do this split sooner, rather than later, so as to not tie up IPython core dev time on reviewing these improvements, and letting them have a more active (less conservative) life outside of ipython proper.  Also pinging @takluyver , who was just reviewing #4017 to see what he thinks.

If this is a high priority thing, I can go ahead and do this split. Maybe
sometime tomorrow morning?

On Tue, Aug 13, 2013 at 4:17 PM, Paul Ivanov notifications@github.comwrote:

> I know @davclark https://github.com/davclark's a bit occupied for the
> time being, but there has recently been more activity, particularly in the
> R magic improvements, that I think it would make sense to do this split
> sooner, rather than later, so as to not tie up IPython core dev time on
> reviewing these improvements, and letting them have a more active (less

>

> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/3803#issuecomment-22604868
> .

#4017 is close to landing, so I'd let that go in first.

It's not exactly high priority, but it seems like there's a few people interested in working on it, and once it's in a separate repo, we'll have a lower threshold for adding committers to it.

@davclark I would be very interested in hearing about what kind of changes/enhancements you and Laurent are intending to pursue for the R magic. Is there a plan already in place somewhere or a list of items you guys intend to address?

(This is getting a bit off-topic but I don't see any way of contacting yo udirectly. My email is gmbecker at ucdavis dot edu if you'd like to take the discussion off-list)

Public is fine for this. But you can add gmail or berkeley.edu to my github
handle and it works.

Laurent is _very_ busy right now, and we're working on getting the testing
infrastructure right so we can consolidate and harden pandas <-> R
data.frame conversion. I'd say this is the most important thing, and it has
nothing to do with ipython (I think).

An issue I'd like to tackle (requested some time ago by Jonathan Taylor,
and addressed partially by your recent patch) - make r_magic return values
behave more nicely (and generally strive to be as nice as knitr / RStudio).
In particular, exception handling should detect an R exception and print it
with formatting!

More medium term, I think it makes sense to slurb the ipython magic into
rpy2. This simplifies logic in the magic (no need to check for rpy2
version-specific features), and also paves the way towards Min's idea for
getting beyond %load_ext, so we can just do:

%import rpy2

But, to be clear, that's just me, not Laurent (yet).

On Wed, Aug 14, 2013 at 2:44 PM, gmbecker notifications@github.com wrote:

> @davclark https://github.com/davclark I would be very interested in
> hearing about what kind of changes/enhancements you and Laurent are
> intending to pursue for the R magic. Is there a plan already in place
> somewhere or a list of items you guys intend to address?
>

> the discussion off-list)
>

> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/3803#issuecomment-22669667
> .

Slightly off-topic also, but if you don't want to create yet-another-organisation to regroup users and give them repo write access, I created IPython-contrib some time ago, I can make you admin of it, or of a sub-team.

I assume you mean me... I'm happy to administer either a magics team or be (I assume) one of the administrators for the repo. If you'd like me to step down in the future to a more limited admin, that's fine.

Yes, I was meaning anyone that would like to have some admininstrative role on a non-IPyton-core repo(s) and/or organisation. Just tell me and I'll create a repo were you are full admin or make you admin of the organisation if you want to create repos yourself.

recapping the discussion from the lab meeting today: we'll break these off, one by one, after contacting the relevant projects to see what they want to do with them (merge them into the projects as part of the repo, or break off the repo and have it be under their organizations).
Whew - saw this just after I created an ipython-rmagic repo. I'll talk to Laurent.

Just a note (Thanks @davclark for bringing this thread to my attention - I am a tad busy at the moment). I have no objection to see `rmagic` moved to `rpy2` (as long as the developers follow, and there are unit tests), or spun off as a package. We can play by ear and see how it goes.

Personally, i'd like to see it kept separate, as there as some things that
I think can be beneficial for the magic to do that don't really have much
or anything to do with the internal communication model that rpy2 provides.

Its not really clear to me why %load_ext rmagic is inherently worse than
import rpy2 in cases where rpy2 functionality is not directly invoked in
python code elsewhere in the notebook. That situation covers essentially
(if not absolutely) all notebooks I'm likely to use the magic for (if I
find myself needing the lower-level capabilities of rpy2, I imagine I would
just use that everywhere in the notebook...).

I'm open to arguments to the contrary, however.

 I admit my use of the magic is likely not particularly standard, at least
right now. I generally write R analyses, as opposed to python ones which
invoke a particular R function. I'm curious what people are generally doing
with the rmagic. Perhaps we should send a message out to the users list or
reach out in some other way to see what people are doing and would like to
do with the various magics.

~G

## 

Gabriel Becker
Graduate Student
Statistics Department
University of California, Davis

@gmbecker
The link between `rmagic` and `rpy2` is: the former synchronized with the later, particularly when newer features are involved.

Having that said, it is almost certainly possible to have newer features needed by `rmagic` part of that `rmagic` package, at least until they appear in `rpy2`. The lower-level interface (`rpy2.rinterface`) aims at making any interface with R possible. `rpy2.robjects`, `rpy2.rpy_classic` (an implementation of the legacy `rpy` interface) are implemented using it.

On a related topic, there is a sub-package `rpy2.interactive` that could benefit from being merged with an ipython+rpy2 effort. As you note there are several possible ways to use ipython with R/rpy2, and the magic might only be one of them. Embedding R figures in an ipython notebook is one such example: http://nbviewer.ipython.org/5180089

I was going to do some work, but now I am just confused. So, I'm officially standing by.

I guess my main question is to @gmbecker: what's your concern? What concerns do others have?

I create new environments all the time, and I like to have to remember the fewest number of packages to install as possible. So, having an extra rmagic package is a -1 here.

To me, the import / export features of the magic are essential and rely on core features of rpy2. If I'm just using R, then I could use RStudio / knitr and get much better e.g., error reporting. 

Are we talking about using rmagic without a depndency on rpy2? rpy2 seems like the right namespace for communicating well with R. As @lgautier suggested, it may make sense to spin off a simple package that allows interaction with an R process. This package could include the necessary hooks to support %load_ext, and be very lightweight, while still providing.

As far as I can understand, the notebook referenced above (http://nbviewer.ipython.org/5180089) is a partial duplication of effort that just went into #4017.  Both even use ggplot as an example. This means we have a less-than-ideal development process. I'd like to fix that.

If the hooks for %load_ext are actually in rpy2, development will obviously be coordinated. There will be no need for special casing the capabilities of the particular version of rpy2 that you're using. As I understand it, the rpy2 API is "allowed" to change at each minor revision.

@ivanov also reported on some thoughts from the last ipython dev meeting. I was reading "package maintainer" relevant to the rmagic to be @lgautier. Is this what was meant?

Hope I'm being helpful!

Yes, we decided to offer the maintainership of the language magics to the maintainers of rpy2, oct2py and cython - each project is welcome to maintain the relevant language magic either as part of its main codebase, or as a separate project (because we think the magics could have more frequent releases than the whole projects at the moment). So rmagic would end up more closely integrated with rpy2, and you'd eventually do something like `%load_ext rpy2` to load it.

If any of those projects aren't interested in maintaining the magics, then we'll probably split them out within the ipython organisation so that we can add more maintainers to them.

@davclark My main concern about direct, low-level integration it is
conceivable to me that we might want the rmagic to have dependencies that
we/you/laurent don't want rpy2 as a whole to have (example discussed below).

On Tue, Aug 20, 2013 at 12:16 PM, Dav Clark notifications@github.comwrote:

> I was going to do some work, but now I am just confused. So, I'm
> officially standing by.
> 
> I guess my main question is to @gmbecker https://github.com/gmbecker:
> what's your concern? What concerns do others have?
> 
> I create new environments all the time, and I like to have to remember the
> fewest number of packages to install as possible. So, having an extra
> rmagic package is a -1 here.
> 
> To me, the import / export features of the magic are essential and rely on
> core features of rpy2. If I'm just using R, then I could use RStudio /
> knitr and get much better e.g., error reporting.

This is personal opinion and directly motivated by what I want to do with
the ipython notebook (both as it exists now and with changes I am making in
a fork that are not relevant here), but I am strongly against "punting" on
the concept of a primarily or exclusively R based notebook. I am not
claiming this is the primary goal of the rmagic, but I think it is a valid
one that it is important (to me at least) to continue to actively support.
That is the reason I fixed up the printing in my pull request.

> Are we talking about using rmagic without a depndency on rpy2? rpy2 seems
> like the right namespace for communicating well with R. As Laurent
> suggested, it may make sense to spin off a simple package that allows
> interaction with an R process. This package could include the necessary
> hooks to support %load_ext, and be very lightweight, while still providing.

So here is the difference in my mind as an R user: rpy2 is for using python
code to do R things, the rmagic is about using R code to do R things. Its a
somewhat subtle distinction, but an important one IMO.

> As far as I can understand, the notebook referenced above is a partial
> duplication of effort that just went into #4017https://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/4017.
> This means we have a less-than-ideal development process. I'd like to fix
> that.

Well the notebook above is strange in a couple of ways, the largest of
which is that the code is python when ALL of the computations are based in
R. In my admittedly biased opinion, the "correct" way to get the
functionality in that notebook is to use a %%R cell magic, which after
#4017https://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/4017will behave
properly and show the plot, as you point out.

So, the dependencies thing.

I have a version of rmagic.py which implements a new cell level magic
called %%Rcaching. This magic behaves like %%R, except that complex,
state/variable dependency based caching is performed. This is done via the
RCacheSuite package I am developing (which will be released soon). I
implemented this because I had the package already and it turns out to be
SUPER useful to have trustable caching when dealing with a notebook that
calls for computations that are expensive. I can change a cell in the
notebook, run the whole thing, and it will only perform computations
actually relevant to the change.

I think this is a valuable thing which should be considered for inclusion
in the rmagic (I'm certainly not going to go back to not using it!), but it
depends on the additional RCacheSuite R package, which has its own
dependencies. I think that is perhaps ok given the gains, but having the
entirety of rpy2 have that added dependency when only the magic benefits
doesn't seem like a win.

~G

> If the hooks for %load_ext are actually in rpy2, development will
> obviously be coordinated. There will be no need for special casing the
> capabilities of the particular version of rpy2 that you're using. As I
> understand it, the rpy2 API is "allowed" to change at each minor revision.
> 
> @ivanov https://github.com/ivanov also reported on some thoughts from
> the last ipython dev meeting. I was reading "package maintainer" relevant
> to the rmagic to be Laurent. Is this what was meant?
> 
> Hope I'm being helpful!
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/3803#issuecomment-22970013
> .

## 

Gabriel Becker
Graduate Student
Statistics Department
University of California, Davis

Cool, that's very helpful. I misunderstood that you might somehow want rmagic to _not_ depend on rpy2. And the caching feature would be awesome.

Honestly, this sounds like it makes sense to have a fancy rmagic supporting things such as caching, and then also make rpy2 support %load_ext in a lightweight way (it's just one file, and it would be simpler logic than the existing rmagic.py). rpy2's %load_ext support could also provide hooks for rmagic, so we avoid code duplication (or not - whatever is easiest). This would also lighten the burden of adopting hard dependencies for rmagic - if someone wants something lightweight, they'd have that choice.

Moving forward, it might make sense to factor the rpy2.interactive.ipython stuff out of rpy2 and into the fancier rmagic. But I think we shoud table that until after the following.

For concrete next steps, I'd suggest I (or someone) do the git subtree approach to factoring out rmagic and the relevant docs. From there, we integrate a minimalistic version into rpy2 (again using git subtree), and then start making the standalone rmagic into the full-featured, high-power approach you suggest.

I'm happy to take responsibility for testing and maintaining the lightweight approach in rpy2 and also pay attention to the bigger rmagic project.

As an aside, are you aware of the way knitr does caching?

@gmbecker

Regarding rpy2's dependencies, that's easy: not even numpy is a dependency. I consider the code using these as providing optional capabilities, only people using them will need the dependencies.

> > Are we talking about using rmagic without a depndency on rpy2? rpy2 seems
> > like the right namespace for communicating well with R. As Laurent
> > suggested, it may make sense to spin off a simple package that allows
> > interaction with an R process. This package could include the necessary
> > hooks to support %load_ext, and be very lightweight, while still providing.

To clarify, rpy2 aims at being the simple package that allows interaction with an R process. To some extent it is only a wrapping of R's C API (with few bells and whistles for Python). The spin off would a package offering features for interactive work (REPL interaction). The (very modest) effort currently in rpy2 looked for example at building `__doc__` string from R documentation on the fly when exposing R packages; something that is fine for interactive work, but would be an unfortunate performance penalty for general scripts. If rmagic and friends are kicked out of the ipython codebase, I am fine to have them in the `interactive` namespace, or out in their own package (and then I'll ask if some of the code currently in `interactive` would be welcome in that `ipython-rmagic` package).

> So here is the difference in my mind as an R user: rpy2 is for using python
> code to do R things, the rmagic is about using R code to do R things. Its a
> somewhat subtle distinction, but an important one IMO.

The fact that rmagic is using rpy2, an all of this is implemented in Python, is blurring the lines you are drawing, if I understand it right.
A general system for parsing and evaluating strings of R code is already in rpy2, for example. The callbacks for designing R GUI exposed in R's C API are also part of rpy2 (letting one build an R console or R GUI in Python - see http://rpy.sourceforge.net/rpy2/doc-2.3/html/related_projects.html#embeddeding-an-r-console) 

> I think this is a valuable thing which should be considered for inclusion
> in the rmagic (I'm certainly not going to go back to not using it!), but it
> depends on the additional RCacheSuite R package, which has its own
> dependencies. I think that is perhaps ok given the gains, but having the
> entirety of rpy2 have that added dependency when only the magic benefits
> doesn't seem like a win.

It would be a soft dependency. The need for it will only manifest itself when rmagic is wanted.
Also, automating the download and install of an R package can be done relatively easily (for example
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/15761756/rpy2-check-if-package-is-installed ).

@davclark 

> Moving forward, it might make sense to factor the rpy2.interactive.ipython stuff out of rpy2 and into the fancier
> rmagic. But I think we shoud table that until after the following.

Anytime you like. `rpy2.interactive` is a bit of a kitchen sink. May be some of it should just go.

To clarify, we're not kicking anything out of IPython. We think it might
make more sense for rmagic to be maintained with rpy2, so we're offering it
to you, but we'll willingly carry on maintaining it if you prefer not to
adopt it.

notifications@github.comwrote:

> like the right namespace for communicating well with R. As Laurent
> suggested, it may make sense to spin off a simple package that allows
> interaction with an R process. This package could include the necessary
> hooks to support %load_ext, and be very lightweight, while still providing.

>  To clarify, rpy2 aims at being the simple package that allows
> interaction with an R process. To some extent it is only a wrapping of R's
> C API (with few bells and whistles for Python). The spin off would a
> package offering features for interactive work (REPL interaction). The
> (very modest) effort currently in rpy2 looked for example at building
> **doc** string from R documentation on the fly when exposing R packages;
> something that is fine for interactive work, but would be an unfortunate
> performance penalty for general scripts. If rmagic and friends are kicked
> out of the ipython codebase, I am fine to have them in the interactivenamespace, or out in their own package (and then I'll ask if some of the
> code currently in interactive would be welcome in that ipython-rmagicpackage).
> 
> So here is the difference in my mind as an R user: rpy2 is for using python
> code to do R things, the rmagic is about using R code to do R things. Its a
> somewhat subtle distinction, but an important one IMO.
> 
> The fact that rmagic is using rpy2, an all of this is implemented in
> Python, is blurring the lines you are drawing, if I understand it right.
> A general system for parsing and evaluating strings of R code is already
> in rpy2, for example. The callbacks for designing R GUI exposed in R's C
> API are also part of rpy2 (letting one build an R console or R GUI in
> Python - see
> http://rpy.sourceforge.net/rpy2/doc-2.3/html/related_projects.html#embeddeding-an-r-console)

I respectfully disagree. Using the %%R magic is _conceptually_ different,
from a notebook author's perspective, than doing rpy2.robjects.r("<my r
code here>").

Yes, in the highly technical sense

%%R
x = rnorm(10)
plot(x)

is a piece of ipython code, but that isn't how anyone is thinking about it,
and it is not how people SHOULD be thinking about it.

In my opinion thinking about the above a piece of (i)python code is
actively detrimental to understanding what is going on at the level that a
notebook author should be thinking about it, in much the same way that
considering the lapply function in R a piece of C code (which as an R
function which almost immediately calls .Internal it essentially is) would
be missing the point.

Lets take this to the extreme. Some of my notebooks are such that all the
code cells are %%R magics (other than the %load_ext at the beginning). Are
the analyses performed by those notebooks written in python or R? I think
it is entirely clear as both a conceptual and practical matter that they
are written in R, regadless of the fact that technically they are written
in ipython and use rpy2.

I admit that the %R line magic is much muddier and am perfectly willing to
stipulate that that IS (virtually) equivalent to rpy2.robjects.r(...)

 I think this is a valuable thing which should be considered for inclusion

> in the rmagic (I'm certainly not going to go back to not using it!), but it
> depends on the additional RCacheSuite R package, which has its own
> dependencies. I think that is perhaps ok given the gains, but having the
> entirety of rpy2 have that added dependency when only the magic benefits
> doesn't seem like a win.
> 
> It would be a soft dependency. The need for it will only manifest itself
> when rmagic is wanted.
> Also, automating the download and install of an R package can be done
> relatively easily (for example
> 
> http://stackoverflow.com/questions/15761756/rpy2-check-if-package-is-installed).
> 
> Automatically installing packages without user input or oversight is
> somewhat worrying to me, but I see your point about soft dependencies. If
> everyone else thinks the rmagic should live in/be maintained by rpy2 I am
> not one to dig my feet in and try to push against a mountain.

I just worry that the "this is python code" philosophy of rpy2 (which is
appropriate for rpy2) may not be the right one for building what I think
the rmagic was intended to be and may threaten or de-emphasize features
which the magic could benefit from. But maybe that conception of mine is
just way off and I'm the only one who is/ever will be using the notebook
the way that I do.

~G

## 

Gabriel Becker
Graduate Student
Statistics Department
University of California, Davis

ok, so sounds like @gmbecker is arguing for the rmagic to be its own repo, but we still think it makes more sense to have it live under the rpy2 organization, since the implementation of %%R today relies heavily on rpy2. Another reason to not have this repo be a part of the ipython organization is that it would allow there to exist another package in the future that perhaps implements the %%R magic without using rpy2, and @takluyver is just writing up something to that effect which will get posted here shortly.

On Wed, Aug 21, 2013 at 3:22 PM, Dav Clark notifications@github.com wrote:

> <snip>
> 
> As an aside, are you aware of the way knitr does caching?

@davclark

I am. It is _much_ better than nothing but there are some problems with it:
- It is not implemented in a way that other code can use (it is buried
  deep within the knitr code with no API for my code to get at)
- It has the concept of automatically detecting dependencies between
  code chunks, but unfortunately it doesn't work in some common cases (a
  simple example is that it doesn't understand that the expression x=x+5
  depends on the variable x)
- It hashes the code as a string instead of as parsed expressions,
  meaning adding a space invalidates the cache (this is silly and easily
  fixed, but they haven't done so. I don't know why)
- It implements a one cache at a time system, and checks only the names
  of the variables a chunk depends on to determine whether the cache should
  be used. New cached values overwrite existing ones

The first and last point are the biggest problems for what I want and the
primary reasons I created RCacheSuite. My research is in non-linear
documents that have multiple paths through them, so the paradigm of
overwriting the old cache with a new one simply won't work in my use-case;
I need a single block of code to be associated with multiple caches.
Furthermore, RCacheSuite does have an API that can easily be slotted in
wherever R code is being evaluated via  function call, thus the ease with
which I created the %%Rcaching magic

That was probably more info than you were looking for, but there you go :)

~G

> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/ipython/ipython/issues/3803#issuecomment-23055192

## 

Gabriel Becker
Graduate Student
Statistics Department
University of California, Davis

On 22 August 2013 11:38, gmbecker notifications@github.com wrote:

> I just worry that the "this is python code" philosophy of rpy2 (which is
> appropriate for rpy2) may not be the right one for building what I think
> the rmagic was intended to be and may threaten or de-emphasize features
> which the magic could benefit from. But maybe that conception of mine is
> just way off and I'm the only one who is/ever will be using the notebook
> the way that I do.

While rmagic is 'R code', one of the key features for me is that it can use
Python objects - that is, I can pass data structures easily between the
Python code and the R code, to do analysis in a mixture of the two
languages. In my case, that's mostly Python code with snippets of R where
Python doesn't have the function I need, but other mixtures are possible.
This is why rmagic is built on rpy2, which handles converting data back and
forth, rather than a simpler setup that just pipes raw R code into an
interpreter.

The case of having a pure R notebook is where it would make sense to have a
separate R kernel - one that can run code in R without needing a cell magic
on every cell. That hasn't been written for R yet, but we are supporting
other languages at that level as well (e.g. Julia is using it). That's
probably quite a separate codebase from rmagic, which allows mixing R code
into your Python notebook (although one way of writing an R kernel would be
to write it in Python calling into R).

Thomas
